quiz.title: Chemistry Grade 12: Unit 10 Quiz 6
quiz.subtitle: 10.6: Entropy Predictions
quiz.subject: Chemistry
quiz.topic: Predicting the sign of entropy changes in chemical and physical processes

questions.question: In which of the following reactions is the entropy change ($\Delta S$) expected to be most positive?
questions.explanation: The decomposition of calcium carbonate produces a mole of gas from a solid, which represents a massive increase in the number of microstates and disorder.

questions.question: What is the expected sign of $\Delta S$ for the reaction: $2SO_{2}(g) + O_{2}(g) \rightarrow 2SO_{3}(g)$?
questions.explanation: There are 3 moles of gaseous reactants producing only 2 moles of gaseous product. A decrease in the number of gas moles leads to a decrease in entropy.

questions.question: When a gas is compressed at constant temperature, the entropy of the gas:
questions.explanation: Reducing the volume limits the space in which molecules can move, reducing the number of available positional microstates.

questions.question: Predict the sign of $\Delta S$ for the process: $I_{2}(s) \rightarrow I_{2}(g)$ at $25$Â°C.
options: It depends on the mass of iodine.
questions.explanation: Sublimation transitions a substance from a highly ordered solid lattice to a highly disordered gaseous state.

questions.question: Which factor is generally the most important when predicting the sign of $\Delta S$ for a chemical reaction?
options: The change in the number of moles of gas.
The change in the color of the reactants.
The total mass of the products.
questions.explanation: Gases have much higher absolute entropies than solids or liquids, so changes in gas moles usually dominate the overall $\Delta S$ calculation.

questions.question: For the reaction $HCl(g) + NH_{3}(g) \rightarrow NH_{4}Cl(s)$, the entropy change is:
questions.explanation: Two moles of gas react to form one mole of solid; this is a drastic increase in order, resulting in a negative entropy change.

questions.question: If $\Delta n_{gas}$ (moles of gaseous products minus moles of gaseous reactants) is positive, what is likely true of $\Delta S$?
options: $\Delta S$ will be exactly equal to $\Delta n_{gas}$.
questions.explanation: An increase in the quantity of gas molecules typically results in a positive change in the system's entropy.

questions.question: Which of the following describes the entropy change when a liquid crystallizes into a solid?
options: The system becomes more ordered, so $\Delta S$ is negative.
The system becomes more disordered, so $\Delta S$ is positive.
The entropy remains constant because no chemical bonds are broken.
The entropy increases because heat is released.
questions.explanation: Freezing/crystallization reduces the freedom of movement of the particles, leading to a more ordered state.

questions.question: Predict the sign of $\Delta S$ for: $Br_{2}(l) \rightarrow Br_{2}(aq)$.
questions.explanation: Dissolving a liquid in a solvent to form an aqueous solution increases the volume available to the solute molecules, increasing disorder.

questions.question: What happens to the entropy of a system during an isothermal expansion into a vacuum?
questions.explanation: Even though temperature is constant, the gas molecules now have a larger volume to occupy, which increases the number of positional microstates.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You have an intuitive sense for changes in molecular disorder.
scoreMessages.70: Good job. You can accurately predict entropy signs for most reactions.
scoreMessages.50: Satisfactory. Pay close attention to the number of gas moles on each side.
scoreMessages.0: Focus on the physical states (s, l, g) to determine entropy changes.
